title: Deterministic computation of the characteristic polynomial in the time of matrix multiplication

sections.previous work:
Previous algorithms based on linear algebra over 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} for computing the
characteristic polynomial of 𝐌∈𝕂m×m𝐌superscript𝕂𝑚𝑚\mathbf{{M}}\in\mathbb{K}^{m\times m} mainly fall in three
types of methods. combining the traces of the first n𝑛n powers of the input matrix using
the Newton identities reveals the coefficients of the characteristic
polynomial. Known as the Faddeev-LeVerrier algorithm, it was introduced in
, refined and rediscovered in
  , and used in  to prove that
the problem is in the 𝒩​𝒞2𝒩superscript𝒞2\mathcal{NC}^{2} parallel complexity class. introduced in  and improved in , this
approach does not involve division, and is therefore well suited for
computing over integral domains. Later developments in this field include
[ref]1 , the latter reaching the best known cost bound of O(m2.6973log(m)c)\mathchoice{O\left(m^{2.6973}\log(m)^{c}\right)}{O(m^{2.6973}\log(m)^{c})}{O(m^{2.6973}\log(m)^{c})}{O(m^{2.6973}\log(m)^{c})}
ring operations using a deterministic algorithm, for some constant c>0𝑐0c>0. based on sequences of iterates of vectors under the application of the
matrix: (𝐯,𝐌𝐯,𝐌2​𝐯,…)𝐯𝐌𝐯superscript𝐌2𝐯…(\mathbf{{v}},\mathbf{{M}}\mathbf{{v}},\mathbf{{M}}^{2}\mathbf{{v}},\ldots). These methods
rely on the fact that the first linear dependency between these iterates
defines a polynomial which divides the characteristic polynomial. Some
algorithms construct the Krylov basis explicitly   , while others can be interpreted as an implicit
Krylov iteration with structured vectors [ref]12 . Methods based on traces of powers use O​(m4)𝑂superscript𝑚4\mathchoice{O\left(m^{4}\right)}{O(m^{4})}{O(m^{4})}{O(m^{4})} or
O​(mω+1)𝑂superscript𝑚𝜔1\mathchoice{O\left(m^{\omega+1}\right)}{O(m^{\omega+1})}{O(m^{\omega+1})}{O(m^{\omega+1})} field operations, and are mostly competitive for
their parallel complexity. Methods based on determinant expansions use
O​(m4)𝑂superscript𝑚4\mathchoice{O\left(m^{4}\right)}{O(m^{4})}{O(m^{4})}{O(m^{4})} or O​(mω+1)𝑂superscript𝑚𝜔1\mathchoice{O\left(m^{\omega+1}\right)}{O(m^{\omega+1})}{O(m^{\omega+1})}{O(m^{\omega+1})} field operations and are
relevant for division-free algorithms. Lastly, the Krylov methods run in
O​(m3)𝑂superscript𝑚3\mathchoice{O\left(m^{3}\right)}{O(m^{3})}{O(m^{3})}{O(m^{3})} [ref]12  or O​(mω​log⁡m)𝑂superscript𝑚𝜔𝑚\mathchoice{O\left(m^{\omega}\log m\right)}{O(m^{\omega}\log m)}{O(m^{\omega}\log m)}{O(m^{\omega}\log m)}  field operations with deterministic algorithms, or in
O​(mω)𝑂superscript𝑚𝜔\mathchoice{O\left(m^{\omega}\right)}{O(m^{\omega})}{O(m^{\omega})}{O(m^{\omega})} field operations with the Las Vegas randomized
algorithm in . Note that the characteristic polynomial of 𝐌𝐌\mathbf{{M}} cannot be computed
faster than the determinant of 𝐌𝐌\mathbf{{M}}, since the latter is the constant
coefficient of the former. Furthermore, under the model of computation trees,
the determinant of m×m𝑚𝑚m\times m matrices cannot be computed faster than
the product of two m×m𝑚𝑚m\times m matrices
[8, Sec. 16.4], a consequence of Baur and
Strassen’s theorem . Another type of characteristic polynomial algorithms is based on operations on
matrices over 𝕂​[x]𝕂delimited-[]𝑥\mathbb{K}[x], called polynomial matrices in what follows. Indeed
the characteristic polynomial may be obtained by calling a determinant
algorithm on the characteristic matrix x​𝐈m−𝐌𝑥subscript𝐈𝑚𝐌x\mathbf{{I}}_{m}-\mathbf{{M}}, which is
in 𝕂​[x]m×m𝕂superscriptdelimited-[]𝑥𝑚𝑚\mathbb{K}[x]^{m\times m}. Existing algorithms, which accept any matrix in
𝕂​[x]m×m𝕂superscriptdelimited-[]𝑥𝑚𝑚\mathbb{K}[x]^{m\times m} of degree d𝑑d as input, include the evaluation-interpolation method, which costs
O​(mω+1​d+m3​𝖬′⁡(d))𝑂superscript𝑚𝜔1𝑑superscript𝑚3superscript𝖬′𝑑\mathchoice{O\left(m^{\omega+1}d+m^{3}\mathchoice{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}\!\left(d\right)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}\right)}{O(m^{\omega+1}d+m^{3}\mathchoice{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}\!\left(d\right)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)})}{O(m^{\omega+1}d+m^{3}\mathchoice{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}\!\left(d\right)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)})}{O(m^{\omega+1}d+m^{3}\mathchoice{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}\!\left(d\right)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)})} field operations,
requires that the field 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} is large enough, and mainly relies on
the computation of about m​d𝑚𝑑md determinants of matrices in
𝕂m×msuperscript𝕂𝑚𝑚\mathbb{K}^{m\times m}; the algorithm of Mulders and Storjohann [ref]36 based on weak
Popov form computation, which uses O​(m3​d2)𝑂superscript𝑚3superscript𝑑2\mathchoice{O\left(m^{3}d^{2}\right)}{O(m^{3}d^{2})}{O(m^{3}d^{2})}{O(m^{3}d^{2})} field
operations; retrieving the determinant as the product of the diagonal entries of
the Smith form, itself computed by a Las Vegas randomized algorithm in
O(mω𝖬′(d)log(m)2)\mathchoice{O\left(m^{\omega}\mathchoice{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}\!\left(d\right)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}\log(m)^{2}\right)}{O(m^{\omega}\mathchoice{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}\!\left(d\right)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}\log(m)^{2})}{O(m^{\omega}\mathchoice{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}\!\left(d\right)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}\log(m)^{2})}{O(m^{\omega}\mathchoice{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}\!\left(d\right)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}\log(m)^{2})} field operations
[45, Prop. 41], assuming 𝖬′⁡(d)∈O​(dω−1)superscript𝖬′𝑑𝑂superscript𝑑𝜔1\mathchoice{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}\!\left(d\right)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(d)}\in\mathchoice{O\left(d^{\omega-1}\right)}{O(d^{\omega-1})}{O(d^{\omega-1})}{O(d^{\omega-1})}; the algorithm based on unimodular triangularization in
, which is deterministic and uses O(mωdlog(d)alog(m)b)\mathchoice{O\left(m^{\omega}d\log(d)^{a}\log(m)^{b}\right)}{O(m^{\omega}d\log(d)^{a}\log(m)^{b})}{O(m^{\omega}d\log(d)^{a}\log(m)^{b})}{O(m^{\omega}d\log(d)^{a}\log(m)^{b})} field operations for some constants a,b∈ℤ>0𝑎𝑏subscriptℤabsent0a,b\in\mathbb{Z}_{>0}. In the last two items the cost bound is, up to logarithmic factors, the same as
the cost of multiplying matrices 𝕂​[x]m×m𝕂superscriptdelimited-[]𝑥𝑚𝑚\mathbb{K}[x]^{m\times m} of degree d𝑑d by
relying on both fast linear algebra over 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} and fast arithmetic in
𝕂​[x]𝕂delimited-[]𝑥\mathbb{K}[x], as showed in . The last two of these cost bounds
do involve factors logarithmic in m𝑚m, whereas the first two have an
exponent on m𝑚m which exceeds ω𝜔\omega. In summary, the fastest characteristic polynomial algorithms either are
randomized or have a cost a logarithmic factor away from the lower bound. This
paper, with Theorem 1.1, bridges this gap by proposing the first
deterministic algorithm with cost O​(mω)𝑂superscript𝑚𝜔\mathchoice{O\left(m^{\omega}\right)}{O(m^{\omega})}{O(m^{\omega})}{O(m^{\omega})}.
